en: Interview with Mali Hubert, 2020-01-10

Interview with Malie Hubert, PhD candidate with the Ecology and Evolutionary Biology department of UT. Hubert discusses her study of the resurgence in plant species after the fire in both natural and urban environments. This is a representative quote from the interview: "If and when this does happen again, I think it's important to know what type of plants are we gonna see coming about. Are we seeing more fire adapted species? Are we seeing the same species that we already there?"

This is a representative quote from the interview: "If and when this does happen again, I think it's important to know what type of plants are we gonna see coming about. Are we seeing more fire adapted species? Are we seeing the same species that we already there?"

Captions in English
Bibliographic Description in MODS
Interview with Mali Hubert, 2020-01-10
Interview Questions
Can you state your name and tell us about how you came to Knoxville?
Which department are you in for graduate school?
Can you tell us about the general interest of your research?
So your initial interest was invasive species after the wildfires?
Can you tell us a little about when you first heard about this fire?
So you and your advisor both saw this as an opportunity?
So you had no immediate experience with the fire?
Had you visited Gatlinburg before?
Can you tell us about the conversations with your colleagues and advisor about the opportunity?
How did you focus your research on the fire and invasive species?
Can you tell us about the first time you went to Gatlinburg after the fire?
Where did you go on that initial visit?
Did yo go other places?
To help visualize the difference between the two kinds of sites, were all the sites affected by the same fire?
So what are you looking for at sites in natural areas versus ones in urban environments?
What is your hypothesis, or what are you hoping to discover with this research?
What were the distinctions between the three levels of severity in the natural site?
What plant species were you looking at?
Can you compare that with what you found in the urban sites?
Did the greater amount of diversity in the urban sites surprise you?
What was your reaction when you realized that your intial hypothesis was wrong?
Is your research project still continuing?
How did your focus on invasive species play into this research?
How did your focus on invasive species play into this research?
Are you seeing invasive species taking advantage of this fire?
So the natural species are holding their own? Are they all coming back or just specific ones?
When you picked your sites, was it limited to specific species or areas?
How can this research be built on going forward?
What would be the impact of this research on the public?
Will this fire happen again?
Did anything good come out of this from an ecological perspective?
In the wider context of the research, what should we as th epublic understand?
Now that it's been three years, what is your response when you see the forest?
Is there anything else that you would like to share about your experience?
These people whose land you may be surveyng in Gatlinburg, did any of them lose property or houses?
Anything else you would like to share?
